description:
There's a thief in your house - try to catch him or escape successfully (as thief)

Players take turns moving their pawn on the track. The thief needs to reach space 50 and then return to 1 to escape, and has a headstart of two turns. Certain space apply special effects when you land on them.

If any other player can leave before the thief escapes he/she's the winner.

A simple promotional race game in the tradition of Game of Goose. Move by die roll. If you land on a red number (advantage - see event list on the map), blue number (disadvantage - dito) follow instructions. The first to reach space 90 exactly is the winner.
note:
likely published during mid 1950s

SCAPE is a game based on an escape attempt by British and Commonwealth prisoners of war from Stalag Luft III (a German POW camp) during World War II. Can the British and commonwealth prisoners escape? Only one of them? None?

During the game, players have to play cards in order to make the tunnel or play the action on the card in order to know who's who. In turn order, the active player has to play a card (if possible) and pass the turn until all the cards of the game are played. There are two ways to play cards:

1) FACE DOWN: Place a tunnel card in the center of the table to complete the word "SCAPE". If another card with same letter has already been played this way, you have to play it on top.

2) FACE UP: Play the action indicated on the card, then discard it, showing the letter and identity of the card.
 Finish your turn by drawing until you have four cards (if able), then the player on your right becomes active.

When all the cards have been played, the first card of each tunnel pile is revealed. If the SCAPE word is not complete, the “SS” player wins the game. If there is any card with the "SS" identity revealed in any heap, the "SS" player wins; otherwise, the team (RAF/USAF) with most heaps with its affiliation wins the game.

It is 1882, and the Old Ones are already here.

They arrived seven hundred years ago and have been ruling the planet ever since. The majority of people just get on with their lives, accepting their monstrous rulers. However, a growing band of revolutionaries wish to free mankind from their slavery. These freedom fighters call themselves the Restorationists. A secret war has already broken out between the Restorationists and the forces loyal to the Old Ones. The invention of dynamite has changed the balance of power, and a lone assassin now has the capacity to destroy an Old One. In this shadow world of assassins, informers, police agents and anarchists, nobody is quite sure who is who and which side they fight for.

The game A Study in Emerald draws its central plot from the award-winning short story penned by Neil Gaiman, in which the worlds of Sherlock Holmes and H.P. Lovecraft are combined to telling effect. However, to create a world detailed enough for players, much has been added from real history. The nineteenth century was a time of unrest, with many colorful characters fighting both for and against the authorities. A Study in Emerald is the outcome of the merging of these three worlds.

This second edition of A Study in Emerald sports new artwork by Ian O'Toole and Tatiana Kuzilova along with a streamlined set of rules that will hopefully help those folks who found the first version a tad complicated. Inconsistencies have been removed and the number of available actions has been reduced to the minimum, whilst still retaining the mood of paranoia from the first edition.

Roll and move a game where the aim is to decrease the number of pounds of weight decided by mutual agreement at the beginning of each game and achieve a healthy weight. Reaching it is not easy ... you'll have to have a lot of luck and when you get close to winning your opponents will tend countless traps and invite you to dinner and forcing you to eat more meals possible.

Knight's Journey is a game about Knights going on quest for honor and glory. During their quest they collect gold and information, and bring gold to orphans, church and women they love. 
This is pickup and delivery game that is played on the chess board using chess pieces and tokens. There are two type of tokens gold and information. Players play with knights, and pawns, queens and bishops are the pieces they are trying to collect. information is used to move pieces toward opponent to block him or make him lose points. You can also attack opponent to get his gold. The game is for 2 players, but there's a variant for 3 or 4.
In the files section you can find rules for the game, and tokens you can print.
A simple fast treatment of a small Great Northern War Battle. Find Rules and Vassal Module in Files section this page.

Rommel’s Greatest Victory

On 26 May, 1942, Erwin Rommel launched a strong right hook into the desert, flanking the minefields and fortifications painstakingly built by the British to protect Tobruk. Against heavy odds and in a tensely contested battle, Colonel General Erwin Rommel defeated the British and recaptured Tobruk, earning himself a Field Marshal’s baton in the process.

Rommel At Gazala is the 2nd Edition of Jim Werbaneth’s simulation of the daring offensive of Panzerarmee Afrika against the British Eighth Army’s fortified line near Gazala, Libya, in May and June 1941.

Rommel at Gazala is a quick-playing, accessible game. It is sufficiently easy for new players to enter into board wargaming, but with enough possibilities to offer significant replay value to newcomer and veteran player alike. Counter density is low, letting the players concentrate on strategy more than minutiae, and the pace is fast. There are also special rules to evoke the special flavor of the battle; armor superiority, the dreaded “88,” fortifications, and of course the special capabilities of Erwin Rommel himself.

Game Scale:
Turn: 2 days
Hex: 3 miles / 4.8 kilometers
Units: Battalion to Division

Game Inventory:
Two 11 x 17.5" full-color mapsheets
One dual-side printed countersheets (72 5/8" counters)
One 16-page Rommel at Gazala rules booklet
Two dual-side printed Player Aid cards
One 6-sided die

Complexity: Low
Solitaire Suitability: Medium
Players: 1 or more
Playing Time: 1-2 Hours

The legendary distance and one of the most famous track and field races is the 1,500 meters. In this game, you're one of the eight runners in a 1500 m race.
 1500 m  has a luck-free movement system and uses Euro mechanics: bidding and management. Players always choose in every round how much they advance, but you have to manage your 100 mental strength points over the whole of the race.

Each round has three phases:


    Card phase: Each player chooses a movement card and there is a simultaneous bid (using mental strength points) for winning an advantage action.
    Pace phase: Each player can keep, increase, or decrease their current pace (spending mental strength points).  
    Extra mental strength points cost phase: Runners spend extra mental stength points because of wear and according to their positions.


Using your strategy correctly and knowing when to take risks, you can become the next 1500m champion.

The game includes rules for dummy runners as well as rules for a shorter 800-meter race.

Players searching for hedgehogs in the cage are moving forward with a unique system based on the combination of 66 different illustrated playing cards, using motifs from popular novels by Jaroslav Foglara.
Players move towards the target using playing cards that move forward them or slow down other players. Winner is the player that first reaches the middle of the board.

A hilariously intense card game that combines fist bumps, mind games and good ol' Rock Paper Scissors.

Two players compete by throwing rock paper or scissors to play the corresponding card on their play area. These cards have various effects and deal damage to a player's opponent. The first player to reduce his opponent's life to 0 is declared the victor.

Gwent is a standalone card game included inside the Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt videogame by CD Projekt Red. It is available as a physical copy with the Xbox One Collector's Edition of the video game (Northern Realms and Nilfgaardian Empire factions) and in "Hearts of Stone"physical expansion for PC/PS4 (Scoia'Tel and Monsters factions).

Gwent has two players simulating a war between two of four factions: Northern Realms, Scoia'Tael, Monsters, or Nilfgaardian Empire. Players take turns adding strength to the battlefield until both players pass. The highest strength on the battlefield wins the round and matches are played best of three, with little to no card drawing in between rounds. Special cards may also be played to reduce the effect of certain unit types. Gwent also features various once-per-game leader abilities and deck building rules.

100 Swords: The Red Dragon's Dungeon is a sword based dungeon crawling micro deck builder! Load up with as much as you can carry and run head first into the dungeon, exploring rooms and revealing monsters, all while keeping track of hidden treasures and swords!

During play, you must efficiently play the 5 cards in your hand for any combination of movement, strength, or energy. Movement advances you deeper into the dungeon allowing you to peek at or reveal the cards along the way. Monsters you find can only be defeated with strength. New items (and swords!) are acquired by spending cards in your hand for energy. Many items have effects that will further expand your tactical options as your deck grows.

As you defeat monsters and pick up loot, do your best to remember where everything is hidden. Treasures and slain monsters are worth gold, so get collecting! Once the dungeon has been thoroughly ransacked, or the boss is defeated, whoever has the most gold wins!

Fighting Sail: Fleet Actions 1775–1815 is a tabletop miniatures wargame of fleet battles in the age of canvas, cannon, and timbers. Players take on the roles of fleet admirals in battles ranging from the American War of Independence to the Napoleonic Wars and the War of 1812. Each fleet has access to different ships, tactics, and command personalities - each with its own strengths and weaknesses. Offering a unique blend of detail and simplicity, the scenarios included enable the recreation of historic actions or 'what-if' scenarios.

The rules are designed for 1/1200 scale ship miniatures, although they can be easily adjusted for smaller scales. Game focus is on ships of 6th Rate or above. The game is hex-less, so uses movement and turning templates along with a tape measure or ruler.  Combat and other tests utilize a pool of six-sided dice.

Fighting Sail was designed with a crew-centric approach and has a goal of immersion over simulation. To perform actions players roll a number of dice based on crew and ship capability to test against a target number.  More successes return a better result (more movement, more hits in combat, more damage saves, etc.). The goal of the game is to break the enemy fleet by reducing their morale to zero.  Morale can be lost by taking damage, suffering a collision, or when a ship is taken out of action (by striking, being sunk, or captured in a boarding action).

The Fighting Sail rules include a points-based system for building fleets and balancing scenarios.  The ship/crew capabilities and special rules for eight fleets are detailed in the book (including privateers and pirates).  Six general engagement scenarios are described to get prospective admirals started on their journey into the adventurous age of fighting sail.

User Summary

Players take control of either the Bianco or Nero cat mafia families and lead their side to victory in a series of face-offs.

At the beginning of each face-off, players choose a boss from their initial hand of 5 cards.  That card is then placed, face down on the table in front of them.  From there, players go back and forth playing one or two cards to raise their attack value above their opponents.  When someone finally passes, the owner of the last card played scores a successful attack.  The winner of the face-of then chooses one of their opponents cards and scores points equal to the number of paw prints.

After several face-offs, points are tallied and the player with the highest amount wins the battle.  The first player to win 3 battles sees his family come out on top.

HEXEH: La conquista ("HEXEH: The conquest") is a military strategy game, where up to 4 friends will play against each other in 1vs1, 1vs1vs1, 1vs1vs1vs1 or 2vs2 team style. It resembles a board-game version of the popular "Age of Empires" franchise. The main objective is to eliminate your adversaries, by destroying their main settlement. In order to achieve that, you'll have to explore the map, collect resources with your workers and train military units which you'll use to attack your enemies!

Spanish description:
"HEXEH La conquista" es un juego de estrategia militar en el cual se podrán enfrentar hasta 4 jugadores en las modalidades de 1vs1, 1vs1vs1, 1vs1vs1vs1 o en equipos 2vs2. De características similares al "Age of Empires". El objetivo es eliminar a tu enemigo. Al destruir su asentamiento quedará automáticamente eliminado. Para hacerlo deberás explorar territorios y recolectar recursos con tus trabajadores para poder generar guerreros y atacar!

Join adventurers in the year 1010 after the fall of Bosparan. The Kingdom of Raul fears for the fate and safety of Emperor Hal, who has disappeared without a trace on a hunting trip in the Bornland. While the heir apparent, Brin of Gareth, searches for his father, discord is sown in the capital city by the influential noble Answin in a bid for the throne. The orcs in the Middle Kingdom plot to make haste and take advantage of this prime opportunity! Thousands pour forth, warlike in their midnight furs, from Orkland and scour the country with fire and death. Desperately, Prince Brin gathers his remaining followers to face the hordes of the Aikar Brazoragh, the chief chosen by the Ork gods, on the battlefield. While the third Orc invasion rages in Aventuria, the cards to power and prestige will be reshuffled in the glamorous Gareth capital city. Here the adventure begins!

In Orkensturm, the players take on the roles of those who have stayed behind in the Imperial City of Gareth. Will you choose to support Emperor Answin, the Usurper or the Rightful Heir to the throne, Brin of Gareth? Will Prince Brin succeed in routing the orcs and return home victorious from the battlefield? Or will he perish in battle, Answin remaining the only hope of the Middle Kingdom as a strong ruler? Which of them triumphs is uncertain, because the orc invasion has many possible outcomes. The players can exert their influence to support one of the factions — with direct effects on the end of the story.

Orkensturm is a board game for 3-8 players, age 14 and above, with more than 200 cards, eight different colored tiles sets and a large game board with illustrations from the World of the Black Eye by artist Nadine Schäkel.

After the defeat at Stalingrad and destruction of the 6th Army, the Wehrmacht has regained strength and it is ready to inflict the Soviets a Tactical defeat around Kursk, where huge Soviet forces are massing in preparation of the summer offensive.
In the first days of July, thousands of tanks will fight the greatest tank battle in history.

KURSK 1943 is a new concept game covering greatest tank battle in history fought in Russia in July 1943.

Developed on wooden blocks, over a colorful 86x64 cm mapboard, 400g thick.
The over 200 wooden/plastic components have been created by the best Italian artisinal industry and painted "A buratto", a technique usually adopted for painting car parts and accessories.

Historical Background
In July 1943, the Germans tried the last gambit in the East before the initiative switched (and remained) to the Soviets. 
The Heer planned an offensive around the Kursk salient with the aim to annihilate the huge concentration of Soviet forces massing in the area. The outcome was the largest tank battle in history with tousands of tanks involved in close combat fights for days.

KURSK 1943 is a game for two players, one controls the Germans and the other one controls the Soviets.
Although based on history, players in command of the two sides can modify the evolution of the battle and of the history in the Eastern Front.

Rules Introduction
The rules are easy - 6 pages - players can start playing the game without too many rules to remember and the game is 5 turn long (90-120 minutes)
Then the 10 Optional Rules provide more specific and detailed rules for an enhanced realism, such as special Tank abilities (Blitz, Tiger Battallion, Charge), Soviet Minefields and Maskirovka, Retreat, Combined Attack, Morale...

Scale
A cm is approximately 7 km.
A turn is 5 'days' long.
A full strength counter represents a Leader or a Division (a Corps for the Soviets).

Fog of War
The game must be played with the Fog of War on (wooden blocks are placed on the map in such a way the opponent player can not see them).

Language: English, German, French, Spanish and Italian
Genre: Tactic
Turns: Turn-Based
Complexity: Entry Level to Basic, depending on which rules are used
Period: WW2

Adventure Time Fluxx, as with all Fluxx card games, starts with one basic rule: Draw one card, Play one card. You start with a hand of three cards, so add the card you drew to your hand, and then choose one card to play, following the directions written on your chosen card.

As cards are drawn and played from the deck, the rules of the game change from how many cards are drawn, played or even how many cards you can hold at the end of your turn. No one can win until a Goal card sets the conditions for winning, which is typically collecting certain Keeper cards in front of you. Goals can keep changing, though, so you never know for sure how to win.

With Adventure Time Fluxx, you get to join Jake the dog and Finn the human for some ever-changing fun. Draw a card, Play a card, and change the Rules. Get Mathematical against Candy Zombies, visit the City of Thieves to steal from your friends, and maybe, if things work out just right, you might even get to Floop the Pig!

You are the leader of a band of mercenaries funded by an employer to take control of a location and rid it of your employer's enemies.Your home is dud of a safe haven planet to which your ancestors fled from an unwinnable war. Turns out the planet's wildlife is more of a threat than the war was. Now most people are doing what they can to survive, while those few that thrive aim to mold this new world as they see fit.

Players spend currency called Clips, which is provided by controlled bases, to hire differing levels of troopers, based on the amount spent to hire, and summon them to Base Spaces they control on a hexagon girded map consisting of various different terrain types.

Players selectively draw cards from a personal deck into their hand. Players spend Clips to purchase Tier Cards and summon them from their hand of cards to a base they control. There are three tire types, Blue Tier, Green Tier, and Red Tier, each with different types of corresponding weapons and armor cards. Tire color types and sub-types determine the effectiveness of different types of weapons vs. different types of armor and vice versa. The more Tier cards of a color the player has attached to bases they control the better the items, of the matching color, they can equip from their hand to troopers.

Once players have troopers on the map they then spend movement points to maneuver their troopers around the map in an effort to defeat their opponents by utilizing terrain spaces which conceal troopers to keep their tier investments a secret, eliminating enemy troopers in combat, capturing neutral/enemy bases, stealing enemy tech, exploring dangerous ruins for lost technology that could aid their efforts, and visiting settlements which will challenge their wits and offer beneficial trading options.

Combat is initiated when a trooper attacks a target that is within range of their equipped weapon at which point an eight sided die is rolled. If the number rolled plus the level of the attacking trooper is greater than the level of the target plus any modifiers, then the attack hits and damage is calculated based on weapon and armor types and sub-types.

[EN]
Alpens 1873, el joc will guide you back to the 9th of July 1873 in Alpens (Catalonia) during the Third Carlist War, which opposed the Carlist troops against the Liberal army. Your villagers must find their way out of town! Don't let the soldiers stop you!

[CAT]
Alpens 1873, el joc us portarà a Alpens, el dia 9 de juliol de 1873 durant la tercera guerra carlina, que enfrontava les tropes liberals contra les tropes carlines. Els teus habitants han de fugir del poble!!! Que no t’ho impedeixin les tropes!!!

From the back of the box (translated):
Japan's largest coup, the Honnoji Incident, happened before dawn on June 2, 1582. Inside the burning temple, Oda Nobunaga is said to have committed suicide but his body was never found....

User description:
Honnoji uses tiles to select action locations, including movement, tile pickup, fighting, and recovery. The tiles are placed in a grid in front of the player, and the actions that happen are determined by the relative locations of the tiles.

While the temple burns, you must move your samurai through the temple, collecting treasures (tiles) and avoiding other samurai and the fire. The winner will be the player who has collected and (managed to keep) the most treasure at the end of 6 rounds.

Chip Up! is the fast-playing dice game that will have you stealing stacks of chips from your opponents or from the pot! Roll the dice to reveal which chip colors are fair game and whose chips are at risk. Play it safe by banking chips when you have the chance, or push your luck to add to your stack instead. When the pot is empty, the game is over and the tallest stack wins!
A word game, where players have to place letter tiles on a board to create words, trying to achieve more points than the opponent.

Four pizzerias, four city districts and four groups of starving customers… It is here, where Gill Bates created his Micropizzas while listening to Jack Michaelson singing “Eat it”. It is also here where the world-famous scientist, Stevie Falconing, is looking for holes in dough and Beat Oven composed his Grosse Funghi…

Pizza Wars PL is a hilarious game for both children and adults in which you take over as an owner of one of four pizzerias and you compete with others, trying to pay the credit off, taken to set up your business. With every baked pizza, you are one step closer to achieve your target..!
Will you meet all your customers’ needs or will you rather meet… a debt collector..?

In Pizza Wars PL, you run a pizzeria in one of four districts of the city Margherita. These are: 

     business district,
     bohemian, 
     villa 
     district of poverty. 


There are 15 unique customers (customer cards) originating from each of them (a total of 60). Each player starts with a different game board and some money.
As an owner of the premises in a given social background you possess a special feature (fixed bonus) helping you to serve guests from your neighbourhood. During the game you can also acquire an extra piece of equipment:

     fridge 
     oven
     trolley
     table
     “connections” 


These increases your chance of victory and modify the strategy.

Each customer requires a pizza with particular ingredients that you have to acquire to bake (cards of ingredients). You may buy them from the market place (on display) or draw randomly for free from the deck. After each round the market place changes (ingredients rot).

There are as many turns as players and within your turn there are also two phases: 

     you may either collect new ingredients or bake a pizza, 
     pay your credit off (move on the board) or acquire a piece of equipment.


You can have a maximum of 2 customers and 6 ingredients (some bonuses can change this rule) on hand.

Having baked a pizza, your customer pays you some money, one’s card is discarded and you compulsorily draw a new customer – you may decide if you want one from your own district or from the common deck. The money you earn has to be spent on new ingredients and on a rate of the credit. The player who pays the credit off as first, wins the game.

There is an extra set of easier rules for younger children.

Fate of Akalon: Tribes is a 2-4 player combat card game set on the dying continent of Akalon. Players control a tribe of fantasy races in a struggle for survival. Each turn a player will play a card to the battlefield and compare combat values. The winner's card goes to their discard pile, the loser's card to that players cemetery. The winner is the first player to send 30 points worth of combat value to their opponent's cemetery. Each race's deck contains unique thematic powers to influence the combat values when played.

Fate of Akalon: Tribes is a quick, thematic card game that surprises with depth of play belying its simple mechanisms.

Pocket and Biscuit is a game of collecting delicious cookies. Tiles are laid face down (pocket showing) in a 6x6 grid, and players must find the cookies they want to eat. If you start by finding a single cookie, then two, then even three or more, your cookies can add up, but you always have to put something back in your pocket for later.

Players take turns finding cookies until someone's pockets are full, at which point the person with the most cookies wins.

This is a game full of humoristic streaks, Norwegian myths, sensations and celebrities.

In Norsk Galskp (=Norwegian Madness) you win if you are the first player to travel from start through to finish, but on the way you have to do funny tasks that will bring out your true inner madness.In this game you can get the ability to send your opponents into a 4 second slow motion state, draw cards to make the others pick invisible apples from the ceiling every time you shout "apple-picking", or maybe you are the one who has to improvise a "Joik"(=Sami song) whilst the other players clap a beat?

If you bring Norsk Galskap to the check-out till, you're not just buying a game, but moments filled with both madness and laughter. Norsk Galskap takes but 20 seconds to learn, and will make holidays, cabin-trips and Friday nights into stories and events that might never be forgotten.

Centerville is a relatively light board game for 2-4 players. Centerville abstractly models the growth and management of a small city — perhaps not unlike the one you're in right now.

Players act as entrepreneurs, tycoons, politicians, and other local movers and shakers working to develop a modern urban area. Fortunes will be made and fame will rise. As time goes by, personal milestones will enrich the players even further.

Throughout the game, players will roll six dice, keeping some and rerolling others, then implementing the various die faces on the game board. This will result in political offices being gained and lost, new vocations learned, new land acquired, or new buildings constructed. The end result is a vibrant community revered near and wide — but only the player who has best balanced their wealth and prestige will emerge the final victor.

Playing time is 15-20 minutes per player.

It's a deduction game in which each player takes a secret role.
There is a big variation of roles with different abilities, but the essential ones are the murderers, their spy, the cup and the victims.

The game starts and the cup knows one murderer and the spy. Each day after discussion players vote to lynch one player, who is eliminated without making known his identity, and without participating for the rest of the game. After the day, during the night murderers show to the already eliminated players, who they are killing.

Game ends if all murderers are killed, or if the number of murderers is the same with all the 'good' players.

Biergarten is designed to be a quick game for a relaxing afternoon with friends, and features 64 individually designed cards with Alpine-inspired architecture and decor.

Biergarten is essentially a tile placement game, and players compete as up-and-coming restaurant owners expanding their outdoor patios, or biergartens. Each card features either one or two colors, as well as  a wall segment on one, two, or three sides of the card. Players earn points for each color match that they make, and having a match between each of the four colors earns a bonus of three points. Watch out for walls -- they block the flow of the garden, and color matches can't be made through a wall. However, if players can entirely enclose their biergarten within a continuous wall, they earn a six point bonus.

The first player to fifteen points triggers the victory round, with each player thereafter getting one additional turn to top the winning point value.

Corrotto is a crime/politics themed market game played with a standard deck of cards. Separate the deck into 3 decks, the draw deck A/2/3/4, the Market Deck 5/6/7/8/9 and the board set up 10/Jokers/J/Q/K. Set up all KQJ10s in four rows of same suits placing Jokers on the tens and randomly draw four face up cards from the market deck below the tens. KQs are the Royal Council and the Jacks separate the council from the marketplace. The draw deck is where you legally earn money by drawing cards, the market deck gets drawn into the marketplace when cards are reserved or purchased. Purchase cards with cards of the same color.

When cards are discarded or spent they go face up into the appropriate decks discard section where market cards become the black market and draw cards become heists. To do illegal actions such as purchasing from the Black Market or perform a heist you must bribe a face card by placing a card higher than previous card of the same suit on the card taking lower bribe into your hand. Anyone can bribe a Jack but you must pay off a Royal for there loyalty. Pay off Queens first which cost 25 Of its suit minus the Jack bribe, same for king but also minus the Queen bribe, place a player marker on Royal. Royal bribes are always scored as end points but the game ends and scores differently in ways of play.

There are 3 different variants of Corrotto: Ladies First, Hot Potato and Rat Race.

New edition of the well known party game Activity where you have to describe words verbal, pantomimic or by drawing. In this edition, players do not play in teams anymore, but try to get as many points for only themselves. The cards show 4 different words, as well as the way you need to explain them (verbally, pantomimic, by drawing). The rules are slightly changed so that it works without teams. Points are given to the player who guesses right and the player who acted, described or drew the words.

"Sjansen" is a Dutch word for flirting. It's a tongue in cheek game about flirting.

From the publisher's website:
In the bar, at courtside or in class rooms: flirting is possible everywhere. Nevertheless one is better at it than the other. Fortunately a game exists that teaches you flirting in three simple lessons. Decide how far you will go and with whom.

It's a matter of luck, an enormous challenge, but above all it's a tactical game. Newbies need practise, others are naturals. Anyway every single student needs to do it often. Everyone gets the same lessons but not everyone will learn as fast. Mixed signals, it's all there. Take your chance and maybe you will find Mr. or Mrs. Right this way!

Translated from the back of the box:

Find the key hidden inside the caverns and free the knights from the claws of the dragon Gorgotte.

Answering questions will help you discover the hidden caches in the caves.

Use your weapons to combat the monsters and avoid being captured by the Dragon Gorgotte.

Find the keys and free your companion knights and win the game.

Mont a Mots Gorgotte was created with a simple idea in mind: Help young children in the first cycle of education to learn French in an original and playful way. Based on tested tools and expert teachers the family game Mont a Mots is designed to help your children. Offer your child Mont a Mots, a most entertaining tool to assist in the development of your child.

Basically you are a knight battling monsters while traveling around the game board. Caves along the way contain power ups (weapons and healing items) to assist you in your battles. However to obtain them, you must answer questions on cards. These questions are designed to improve your ability to speak and understand French.

The game comes with the box, instructions, game board, 275 questions, 5 cardboard knights, 5 pawn holders, 39 cardboard tokens and one d6.
In Knight-mare Chess each player controls their troops with their knights and the shaman. Players should move their pieces and destroy their opponents with strategy and luck.

Stack 'Em 5 is a highly addictive, unique new board game that has aspects of several classics before it, such as chess, checkers, tic-tac-toe, Connect 4, Go, and even Pente, but on a whole new level, or should I say levels. Think of it as 3D connect 5 on gogo juice! And, unlike all its predecessors, and most strategy games of today, Stack'Em 5 allows for more than 2 players at a time. That being said, it is an incredibly strategic battle for 2 players, however as many as 7 can enjoy it, but with 8 or more we wont take responsibility for what might happen next. You and your family & friends will find a new meaning of competitiveness, making Monopoly Night look like a calm night! It's extremely simple to learn for even the youngest gamer, but will take years to master its strategies, making it challenging for the veteran player as well.

Strategy 101: Every single move counts in the which players try to achieve 5 in-a-row, ball by ball! The fundamental rules take less than a minute to learn, yet the game has the complexity to engage both beginners and experts alike - perfect for the entire family!

Stack 'Em 5 Rules!

Each player chooses a color and takes a set of balls. Players take turns stacking balls on the board, the first player starts by placing his/her first ball within the 9 center rods, after which point play is open to any of the 49 rods. Each and every ball is stacked strategically so that 5-in-a-row is accomplished vertically, horizontally, or diagonally just so long as it forms a straight line from point to point with NO turns. Easy Right! The rotation of play is counter-clockwise with a time limit of 30 seconds per turn,  keeping you on your toes. The board itself spins completely around, either left or right on the center rod, giving the current player the ability to look at all the different angles. Only the current player may move the board, and he/she may do so as mush as they like, until the end of their turn. Once a ball is stacked, it cannot be removed or placed elsewhere, and the players turn is over. There are no restrictions on how balls of different colors are stacked. You may put a ball on any of the 49 rods that are open. Once 7 balls occupy a rod, that rod is full, giving the players a total of 343 possible positions on the board. The goal is to simply block your opponent from getting 5-in-a-row while strategically placing your balls to do just that. Be tactical. Obstruct your opponent(s) while expanding your own “territory”. The game ends when a player has been able to link 5-in-a-row in any way possible.

A family board game for pirates.

in Ortuga, players roll and move around the board, similar to backgammon.  Players collect and transport gold, with the goal of depositing the gold on an island.  In order to remove your markers, you must collect a set of 3 cards, declare "Game Exit" and meet your gold reserve.

To win the game, collect your set of cards and get all your counter off the board.

A version of Cat and Chocolate with everyday scenarios. Each turn, the active player draws an event card depicting a certain crisis they must handle - being chased by bees! Bad breath! Or a long line for the bathroom! The player then chooses one to three item cards from their hand and explains how they use these items to get out of the situation.

Other players then vote on whether or not the active player succeeds; if a majority of players agree, the player keeps the event card. At the beginning of the game, players are secretly divided between Team Cat and Team Chocolate. The game is over when a special "End!" event card is drawn, at which point players reveal their team allegiance and count up the number of event cards they've won for their side. The team with the most event cards is the winner!

The party game with movies you joke about making with friends.

Its an adult themed party game where you get to pick the star and the category for the movie you are developing for the round. But your plot is entirely luck of the draw meaning its picked at random and it can make or break your movie. The judge of the round picks the movie they would most be willing to see... or the best sold. Which-ever way they choose, the first to 3 or 6 - three card combos, wins.

The box contains 300 cards. 100 stars, 100 categories, 100 plots. Players use a hand of 4 stars and 4 categories, choosing 1 of each for their round (unless they have a card that says different.

A card game, set in the Iron Century and created in Italy to be used in school, right after the lessons about the Iron Century (Secolo di Ferro).

Its 103 cards depict five different cultures: Catholics, Reformed, Scientists, Demonic and Pirates.

Card types span from characters (Protagonists and Characters) to Bastions, Objects and Specials. Lots of Attack cards are provided to weaken the enemy cities.

To win, you have to create a city containing figures from all the five cultures.

Played in the classroom, the game entertains the children while helping them remember some key concepts about the Iron Century.

The game has been translated in English and Portuguese by PeterPiers.

P.s. the pre-2015 game prototype featured two additional cultures, Turks and Artists, not ported to the new release.

Children are introduced to their first English words by seeing, hearing, and speaking them.  Included are a pair matching game and a bingo game.  Early exposure to a foreign language promotes children's communication skills and strengthens their self confidence.

The game contains 140 questions, which can be answered by the players. It also contains 10 activity cards with a variety of tasks to be carried out. It basically works like a travel edition of the game Trivial Pursuit.

Side Quest is a dungeon crawling card game that fits in your pocket. With a single deck of cards and a couple of dice you and up to 3 friends can battle your way through a decision-packed dungeon. Fight monsters, grab loot and rescue maidens as you gear up your characters to fight the boss at the end of the dungeon.

Side Quest is a fully co-operative game - if any Heroes (or maidens!) die, the game is lost.

There are a wide range of scenarios to play, including ultra-tough single-player missions, challenging 30 minute pick-up games and lengthy 2 hour dungeon treks. With loads of different Heroes, Monsters and Equipment cards you'll never play the same game twice.

Plan together, fight together, win together!

"3 designers, 6 games, 15 dice."

6 is a collaboration between three game designers to provide a collection of light dice games. The tin contains a collection of dice and rules for six games that can be played with them. The games are:

Airstrike: Drop dice sequentially onto the table to obtain a combination of values positions that ensures your bombers make it home.

Dicey Winks: A dexterity game about launching dice from the '6' tin to land your dice near to a target while displacing your opponent's dice.

Foiled: A dueling simulation and bluffing game about selecting the right dice and maneuvers to strike your opponent to push them off the piste.

Slipstream: A risk management racing game, in which turn order is determined by current score.

Triangles: A bidding game in which you must spot and exploit the highest value triangle that you can land your scoring die inside.

Wrestle: Establish the best hold to limit your opponents opportunities to escape it before running out of strength.

The card passing, hand trading game of playing matchmaker in 1940’s New York.  Great for 1 – 10 players, taking about 10 minutes per game. Hot Pursuit uses 3 cards per player and only needs your hands.  New cards aren’t drawn or played – no table needed!

A modern man, done with his day’s work, steps out of his office tower’s lobby into the busy bustle of a city sidewalk. Just as he is getting his bearings set towards home, he collides with someone.  He apologizes profusely.  She politely excuses herself. He tries to ask if she’s alright but she just scurries off again.  Who was that lovely lady and why was she in such a hurry?  Now, it’s time for you to be a true friend and help this modern man find his missing beauty.

GAMEPLAY: 3 cards are dealt to each player.  Whomever is dealt the Pink card becomes the Jealous Ex bent on sabotaging the game, the person who receives the Blue card is the Modern Man, and everyone else is a friend.  All of the friendly players earn a joint victory by passing and trading until the Pink and Blue cards are both in the Modern Man's hand, facing him.  However, the Jealous Ex wins if he/she can manipulate the Pink and Blue cards together, facing anyone who is not the Modern Man.  ***Extra rules and story for solitaire, 2 players, and team play with player elimination, included!

Strategie Game/Placement Game for two people:

The winner is the first person who can place a pyramid, a strip or a group of stars with his own blocks. In most cases the game is then finished.

Contains 36 triangles in red and blue, 3 sets of each pieces each numbered from 1-6

General Rules:

    An enclosed empty space may never be formed on the playing field.
    Each block must be placed so as to be touching at least one other block on at least one side.
    Star:


6 blocks of the same colour placed together in a hexagon form a star; complete stars (including those which extend into other stars) are only protected against the moves of an opponent, not against the player's own moves.

Course of the Game:
The players decide who shall start. Every player places one block of his colour. All of the blocks must be placed in the playing field before the first player begins moving or exchanging blocks. Only one block can be moved or two blocks exchanged per turn.

Moving:
A player can only move his/her own blocks at random to a new position in the playing field.

Exchanging:
The positions of two blocks may be interchanged in an exchange. A player's own blocks rnay be exchanged regardless of the numbering. A player's blocks rnay only be exchanged with those of an opponent when the numbers of both blocks are the sarne, i.e., 4 for 4.

Formations:

Pyramid:
The placing together of 16 blocks of the same colour in an equal-sided triangle.

Strip:
11 blocks of the same colour in a straight line.

Star group:
Four stars of the same colour extending into one another and containing 16-18 blocks (depending on the form of the group) make up a star group.

A 3-in-1 in which you try to predict the Outcome of the Batter at Bat. The 3 ways are:"LIVE" Batter a Batter; from a Custom Deck of 52-Cards; a Batter from a custom 12-Sided Dice;
Using an 8-card "Master 8" deck, you choose a card that you predict will be the outcome.
The 3 versions of the game each have a different "Outcome":
"LIVE" Interactive version - Predict Outcome of Batter at bat in a live game.
"TABLE" Custom 52-Card Deck version - Predict Outcome of next card to be turned over.
"DICE" Custom 12-Sided Dice version - Predict Outcome of next roll of single 12-sided dice.
Score is kept track with "Game Tokens". Each Player starts with 15-20 (Depending upon Game Set). For each "At Bat", Players put token in and pick a Master 8 card. The Player with the most Game Tokens at the end of the game is the winner!
Discover the CHOUFFE world. Build La Chouffe icons out of bricks in a certain time.

In GameFactory, players lead successful computer game companies that try to create the next big hit. They must build rooms in their offices, hire staff and decide which project will be the next one to bring to market.

GameFactory is a worker placement game with a twist: players start with a small office and only a few options for their workers. They use funds to build new rooms with new capabilities and add them to their office, enabling new placement positions and new options. Players then use staff to build games or spend their work on creating other useful things that help them becoming the next computer game legend.

Game Factory is a game for gamers with over 150 cards, a market board, 45 wooden pieces and more than 100 cardboard markers. Two to four players compete in 90-120 minutes about who wins the most cash in the ever-changing computer gaming market.
